intro: Abarema sumbawaensis, commonly known as the Sumbawa legume, is a species native to the island of Sumbawa in Indonesia. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its distinctive pod fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its leaves are compound, consisting of several oval-shaped leaflets, and it produces small, yellow flowers clustered in racemes. The seeds are enclosed in elongated pods, which split open to release the seeds when mature.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abarema sumbawaensis is primarily native to the Indonesian island of Sumbawa. It is found in the tropical rainforests of this region, which are characterized by high humidity and rich biodiversity. The plant thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is typically found in lowland areas. It is part of the legume family and plays a role in the local ecosystem by contributing to soil fertility. Due to habitat loss, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
